sections.text:
This feature adds tenant-configurable retention policy enforcement for AI-generated artifacts—such as emails, call notes, and next-best-action recommendations—along with their associated audit records. Today, these records can persist indefinitely, creating compliance and governance risk for customers with strict data minimization requirements and increasing our long-term storage and operational burden. By making retention periods configurable per tenant, we support diverse regulatory and contractual obligations without requiring bespoke deployments.

On the backend, we will implement retention rules that determine when AI-generated records (and linked audit records) are considered expired. A scheduled cleanup job will then apply the configured policy by either hard-deleting or anonymizing expired data, while preserving referential integrity (e.g., avoiding broken foreign keys and ensuring dependent objects don’t error). Once a record is expired and processed, it must no longer be accessible via API or UI to any user, effectively enforcing the retention boundary rather than relying on front-end filtering.

To help admins validate that policies are behaving correctly, we will expose retention metadata (e.g., retention status, expiry timestamp, and whether deletion vs. anonymization applies) in admin-facing surfaces and/or APIs. This will enable customers to audit policy outcomes and troubleshoot configuration issues without introducing new access control pathways. Importantly, we will not duplicate existing RBAC or audit event capture mechanisms; instead, we’ll leverage current authorization and audit pipelines and focus purely on retention lifecycle and visibility.

The impact is improved compliance posture (GDPR/CCPA-style minimization, internal retention policies), reduced customer risk around AI-generated content governance, and lower ongoing storage footprint. It also clarifies operational expectations: data will reliably expire based on tenant policy, become inaccessible after expiry, and provide transparent, admin-verifiable signals that retention is being enforced—without expanding the scope of permissions or auditing beyond what already exists.
